How long were you in the Navy for?
21 years.
Did you get a purple heart for being wounded on the...
I did.
I did.
What would you tell people when some other, you know, you're out,
you're in your dress whites for whatever reason,
and you know, 1975, there's, the guys were in Vietnam,
sure, some, you know, guys, there's some,
there's some Cormin, some Metix, some Pilots,
some Aviators might have got purple hearts,
some, some guys from the Sea Wolves or something,
but there's not a lot of Navy guys running around
in 1975, 1980, 1985 that had purple hearts.
What did you say to somebody when they said,
hey, where did you get that purple heart from?
I was on the US's Liberty in 1967 when we were attacked,
and, you know, I got it for Shreppna wounds,
and that was about it, you know.
And no one would ever pry and say, you know,
what the hell happened or what was going on,
how that occurred?
Oh, I think a couple of times, you know,
people would try and pry more out of me,
and I just wouldn't say anything.
I said, I just can't talk about it.
And again, it was because of the threat of fines
and imprisonment if we ever spoke about it.
Being a communications technician,
all of my work that I did was secret,
so trying to keep a secret wasn't something
that was new to me.
I just suppressed it to the point that it was building
up inside me, and finally I had to go to counseling.
Do you still have your clearance?
No, when I retired in 2008, I relinquished my clearance.
They didn't take it away, they didn't relate to it.
I just decided I was 62 years old.
It's time to pull the plug.
As you were serving in the Navy, now it's 1975,
now it's 1979, now it's 1982.
And you know that, you know, you know,
you got ordered to not say anything, which look,
I mean, there's things that I've done
which I'm not allowed to talk about.
And you realize, okay, I might not know everything
about the situation, but I know I'm not allowed to talk about it,
but I'm sure that there's a reason for that
that makes sense and I get it.
You know, was part of you thinking, you know,
this didn't happen the way they say it happened.
This seems like they're covering it up
not for any reasons of national security,
but for other reasons.
Yes, I mean, I, because I worked for the National Security Agency,
they actually did a report in 1980 that was classified
top secret and it was their recap of what happened
to the US's Liberty.
I had a copy of that report on my desk
until I retired from the Navy in 1986.
And I had to turn it back in because it was, you know,
was that report accurate?
No, no.
And I mean, there was information that I knew
should have been in there that had to deal with communications
that didn't reflect those communications.
And the thing that they were trying to report
more than anything else was a lack of communications
that occurred resulting from this 100 mile free zone,
I guess that Israel had declared no ship should enter
into that 100 mile zone off the coast of Sinai.
And apparently our naval adashé in Israel
had told them that we don't have any Navy ships there.
Six fleet confirmed that they didn't have any naval ships there.
And that's, you know, a problem with us traveling by ourselves
that they didn't recognize that we were over there
or they conveniently forgot that we were there.
But there was communications that were supposed to have been sent
to us telling us to move back off the coast
and we never received those communications.
And so that's more about what this report from NSA said.
And it didn't talk about the other intercepts
that had, you know, the aircraft talking to ground control
or talking about the target,
talking about seeing the American flag.
And, you know, I don't know why that didn't come out
until later, but we kept doing freedom of information
act requests trying to get a lot of this documentation
back out in public so the truth could be told.
